positive.review:
Alright, I've put in 250 hours at the time of this review, and still I have not lost my love for this game. In fact my love for this beautiful creation has only grown 100x stronger. The time is now before we all reverse.

It's already the most hours I have put into a steam game in easily the last ten years or more so that's saying something. (yes it's a big part of my life)

I've played a few different gacha games, and I do enjoy the whole aspect of buying things and leveling characters, and getting cosmetics etc. I'm a sucker for that kind of stuff and love to get sucked in cause it's just a lot of fun, but this one is so much different than any of the others I've played.

The thing that first caught my eye was the style of the art. It's so unique compared to anything else I've played. It's like a really dope anime series. You can tell the creators really put some care into this. 

The story and the characters have so much depth and everything connects so perfectly. The whole theme is very interesting to me. I really love how they use real life timelines in human history, and add in so many cool events and people and information throughout our existence. It even led me to google certain things just to learn more to have a better understanding of significance in the story. I did not expect this type of game to be this well done. It is now my most favorite game. For that I absolutely feel that spending some money is more than reasonable. I also feel that the game makers are more generous and fair in comparison to others in my experience.

I really love the whole reading a book feel of the game. I can play this far longer than any other game. It's like reading an amazing book with sick artwork high quality voice acting and cinematic music. I've gone 14 hours straight some days, and I feel compelled to keep going because I want to see what happens next. Not like other games where I get worn out after a couple hours and have to get up and move around. Some of the chapters really got to me emotionally as I really felt a deep connection to characters and empathized for the pain or trials they were going though. Being able to go through specific characters side stories really strengthened my connection with them as you get to see why they are who they are based on where they have come from and trials they have been through. I believe the real difference (for me at least) is how it feels like you are reading a book, and not playing a game. I think that visuals only offer so much where as you get far more when you read something. It's just something else entirely.

I feel like even if you don't spend money you can still enjoy the entire story which is kind of rare for a gacha game. Usually you hit paywalls so hard that you have to spend early to just be able to continue the story.

Now if we touch on the fighting battles RPG aspect of it The system is very Intricately designed. It requires a lot of strategy and planning to form effective victorious strategies. The correct combination of characters will cause them to feed off each other and make you even more powerful. It requires much learning and reading. I think it's brilliantly done, and It doesn't feel like it gets stagnant or old where you find yourself just becoming numb and wanting to rush through as fast as possible becoming a robotic chore.

If you are into a slower paced visual novel with in-depth story telling, and unique characters, cool artwork, music, excellent RPG battle system, and great voice acting. I would 100% recommend this. You will be happy you became a part of this unique world.

Aside from Arknights and maybe Genshin Impact, this was by far one of THE BEST gacha games with the most compelling stories and world building i've ever had the pleasure of reading, give it a shot if you enjoy literary references, characters speaking their native language and accents, an oil painting aesthetic, and a cast of characters that AREN'T falling over for the MC and declaring their undying love for her (nothing wrong with those games, but sometimes it can be a BIT too much, looking at you Cyrene HSR).

It also helps that its a very casual experience, dailies are done in 1-3 minutes, and you only really need 1 solid team to clear everything the main story has to offer.

This game is so good words cant even describe how this is so good. The story,the characters are extremely good. The game is so unique and even tho i recently started playing it. I really don't regret playing this game!! I recommend trying this game out once.


"Don't forget my heart..beats...on..the right"

Came for the "haha bri'ish gacha" memes.
Stayed for the great story and amazing visuals.

The first time my eyes laid upon this game on Qooapp, I fell in love with it. For its artwork, music, but most importantly, for its story plot. I like history and games with theme similar to Assassins' Creed when characters can travel between eras, reminiscing important aspects that became the pinnacle of those eras. Reverse 1999 has been doing a great job in that, esp as a gachage that commonly known as a game that doesnt really have a good story or even a story to begin with. (I mostly play on mobile and only use steam for the HD home screen wallpaper only WWWW)

It's a perfect game for casual because unlike any other gachage that emphasized meta or specific gacha characters just to clear main story without malding, you can clear basically almost any content (not all) in auto (yes, auto battle) not just with S rarity characters, but you can even clear it with only lower rarity characters as long as they have synergy and your characters already strong enough. That's what I really like from Reverse 1999 because it didnt emphasize character monetization that much (e.g. to clear part X, u need to use specific x tactic or use x characters with certain dupes, etc).

The only regret that I have is that I personally dont know where to spend my money because I dont like the skins (or how Bluepoch implemented skin system in the game). Let say, I buy a skin, it came out with a good background art but it will never projected into your home screen because your home screen always projected the suitcase living room (or, gathering room, u name it) which make it a waste. Only the character's costume that get displayed in the home screen. It's not a big deal ofc, but it's just personally I like the skin background also projected or changed the home screen background, too, alonside with the character's skin. 

Overall, It's really a good game, hasnt disappointed me yet, and the story is getting stronger and gripping. I cant wait for the next chapter update. Even if the gameplay kinda boring for some, you wont get bored with the story and you wont' be sorry for trying or giving this game a chance. For me, It's one of a kind gachage for now.

Visual and narrative masterpiece. The game's voice acting/direction and translation improves so much after the first few chapters, which shifted my at first negative impression of it. 

There's amazing quality of life features and quick daily logins. Power creep is a bit of a problem + the global region is behind China, so you'll experience everything later and can get spoiled easily. Important main story details are locked behind past events (you are able to unlock and view them in-game), which I don't like. 

Too much stuff going on in the menus, entire aspects of the game that become useless once you progress. Gameplay wise, all of these different modes need to be cut down and only the best ones should stay. The way many gameplay things are called is confusing and unclear, they went for a more artistic approach when naming them, which is fine, but even after playing for so long I can't remember what's what.

Despite its issues, it remains one of the best gacha games, practically unrivaled in art and design.

I have played since global launch, with over 200 hours on the mobile version; so while I have never left reviews before, I feel qualified to inform.
+ Great gameplay, not too hard to get into but even I have yet to master it. the rules are simple, choose 4 characters, play some cards, deal damage to win. In story stages that is enough to get by. The complexity comes with the harder, but optional, stages where difficulty purposefully spikes. There is where you see how one character may be useless alone but synergies so well with a few others that it breaks the meta. Or one character may be busted in damage alone, but lacks the synergies to keep up. 
+ Great story, I hear that some people find themselves confused at times, which is likely due to most background not being explicitly stated most times. Trust me though, if you just flow with it everything will either make sense, or the part you were hung up on will stop mattering.
+ Gacha is pretty fair. 70 to soft pity, 140 for guarantee rateup. About 20 flat is supplied a month, with another 20 over the course of a version update plus however many from the new story section. It is admittably far from guarantees every version but as a F2P (unless you include cosmetics, which I have bought quite alot) I have managed to get most characters I wanted as they rolled out.
 Reverse is far from perfect, I still feel uncertain about Nautika's story, but I would still recommend this to anyone looking for a good gacha.
 Oh, and theres almost no sexualization of any of the characters, if that matters to you. Closest that I can think to that is that 3 (of the over 100) characters have what I would consider disproportionately large breasts. They aren't even main story characters though, and they aren't ultra sized or anything.

Edit: Found the difficulty wall. End of 6th Chapter has a boss with a recommended level of Insight III, Level 1. Only 5-6 star characters can even reach Insight III, so you'd either need luck of pulling enough 5-6 stars to form a team that can get past that and overpower it, or enough luck to put together a strongly-coherent team to clear it under-par. I haven't had luck with good 4-stars that can be put together well enough, so my only "strong" team just consists of a ton of damage rather than being able to utilise something like Bloodtithe or Dynamo. This isn't good enough to clear it at-level, however, so I'd need to overpower my team to get past it in my case, which I can only do because I've had the fortune of actually getting 5/6-star characters to do so with.

The start of 7th chapter has a recommended Insight II, Level 50 level which is arguably the same thing, since Insight III is almost an expensive "Level 51" upgrade of sorts until you start investing past that lock. Theoretically, it should be easier, as it should be roughly the same minus the previous level being a boss. Instead, the Ch7 level was marginally harder owing to the enemies apparently being able to kill an I-III, L-16 character in a single turn from full health, and punish you for using one of the two readily-available damage types. If you lack four members that do non-Mental damage you're going to have a rougher time, and you need to hope they're not also weak-afflatus or they're probably going to get casually one-tapped, given my own team members who has the same afflatus type as the enemy one-tapping her. It's also really, really reluctant to give me any cards of the character with the most investment, making it impossible to get her ultimate off before the enemies shoot off a daze debuff which hit her in all 15 attempts.

Even so this really isn't much of a problem at all because I can just turn the difficulty down. The "starting" difficulty of the game is the middle tier, with a harder mode unlocked later on, but you also unlock an easier difficulty shortly after, so I can keep going through the story anyway. The second "book" drops difficulty back down because you unlock it much earlier too, so this isn't even a later concern.

So, eh? Still enjoying it, still a positive review.

Gacha games tend to sell themselves on two major factors: 1) The initial storytelling to hook the player, then 2) The character designs individually being strong enough to make people want to fork out money for them. It's for reason 1 that I chose to pick up this game just to spend some time- even if I only got a chapter or 2 into it before hitting a paywall, It'd be a good read.

In the prologue cutscenes before you get access to the game's lobby area, the game did an excellent job establishing most of the plotline and the general atmosphere: It presents itself as focusing on victorian-era london splashed with 'arcanist' magic including a natural magical "Storm" that causes reality to outright collapse in on itself and reverse the flow of time in all but specific areas that are exempt for reasons that even the game's characters are attempting to figure out, and it features a tinge of racism between the non-magic folk, the magic-but-sympathetic folk, and the storm-is-ours-to-purge-mortals folk in a three-way argument, rather than trying to pretend there'd be no divisive difference between magic and non-magic folk, or that the division created should be considered acceptable. It's not mincing words or dressing things up- things suck for everyone, and suck for a variety of reasons each. Gripping. Also Regulus- one of the first characters you meet- reminds me a lot of Rin Penrose despite their apparent differences and that's never going to stop amusing me when she speaks up.

What I then immediately discovered was lesbians. The game does not have an exclusively female cast, and neither does it throw you a cast consisting half of pretty women and half of extremely strange men- no, there are pretty women and bizarre women, and there are handsome men and bizarre men. Still, the majority of the game's cast is women, and this includes the protagonist. There's some flowery-sweet romance, some butterflies-in-the-stomach romance, and some more direct romance with characters that altogether toy with the concept. Never does it outright state any of this, if you really wish to believe otherwise, but it's still implied heavily enough to be pretty clear. Seriously, at one point you have a cutscene image that's just one of the girl's face filling your screen with a gentle smile as she stares directly into the protag's eyes and asks "Hold me."

I will say the writing is not of the best quality. It's not bad, but it does like to wax poetic and dance around loose ideas at times instead of getting to the point, while other times it seriously grabs you by the shoulders and straps you in. The writing involving the male narrator is, I find, the most enjoyable, with the main story following a close second. Character stories- at least those that aren't tied to the main story outright- fall behind that, then finally the female narrator that takes over for some chapters is probably the weakest link. It does all vary a little bit though, and you may disagree on the order.

On that note: the narrator. Because the game throws you into the shoes of the self-established character Vertin, who has their own personality, their own moral compass, even their lines are voice acted, the game takes a side-step around exposition. It doesn't give you the oh-so convenient excuse of amnesia or world-hopping that other gachas do to find a reason to have characters temporarily treat you like a child to explain the basics in the middle of every other cutscene. Vertin knows what's going on, even if you don't, so instead there are conversations you can have 1-to-1 with a narrator-like person on the level select screen (some of them are even mandatory), who speaks to Vertin, but seemingly knowingly is speaking directly at you too. They take full advantage of this- Vertin is quite kind-hearted, and as you know nothing of this world yet, you by extension do not know how deep or how cruel this reality can get. They tell you about it sure- the panic of the Storm being at the wrong time, or the sensation of pale horror of someone being oh-so-slightly too far away from a safe zone when the Storm hits and suddenly there's nothing left of them but a dismembered hand, and not to mention how bad humans can get with one-another amid gang wars and the like even before the two magical factions butting heads with mortals stuck in the middle all hating each others' guts.
So, you almost represent an optimism point. You're reading the story that, potentially can have a happy ending. You're following the all-mighty protagonist of the story around who will presumably pull superpowers out of their ass if necessary to save the day eventually, right? That's how most stories work. But you're talking to someone who is implied to have survived the Storm many, many times. Someone who has seen and even been in the middle of country-wide wars, or gang wars, of outright torture and has seen enough to take an aggressively cynical state. The conversations you have with them balance the two viewpoints to reach a happy middle, acknowledging that things suck, but things can get better. He will, nevertheless, call you stupid several times when doing so, but he's not unwilling to come around to how Vertin feels- and, in the meantime, drop some convenient exposition in the form of revisiting memories or directly asking questions about a topic ongoing in the main story.

I can't say I'm sure of the financial "worth" of the game, but it's been very enjoyable with no colossal roadblocks in the story or events, even as a free-to-play player, which is unlike almost every other gacha I've ever touched.

Also eating beans is apparently a sin worthy of eternal punishment. As you do.

negative.review:
Unplayable on Steamdeck

Before I downloaded the game, I looked into the game and its reviews. I heard good things about the game, so I decided to give it a try. My Wi-Fi isn‚Äôt the best, so it took a little over an hour to complete the download. Once downloaded, it did its in-game download, then went to the Home Screen after finishing. 

The cons:
The game has minimum customization optimizations in the settings, which is really no big deal for me. 
But the biggest issue I have is once I was ready to enter into the game from the home menu, I would encounter issues with screen blackout and the next 15 seconds of in-game audio.
I‚Äôm not sure if this happened to anyone else using the Steam Deck, but the screen would be black, and I could hear the audio for at least 15 seconds before it goes quiet!
I was able to move the cursor around, but the game doesn‚Äôt respond, even though it does acknowledge my cursor existence.
I tried resetting the game, uninstalling, and reinstalling the game. I even checked to see if everything was properly installed and not missing. Nothing works, and I‚Äôm very disappointed! 

The Pros: 
So far from my POV, the music is very harmonious, while the art style and scenes are very beautiful.
From the description, the game really has me intrigued, from the characters to the jaw-dropping scenes and story it has to tell! I really do want to play this game on the deck, but for some unknown reason, it just won‚Äôt play.

Until the game can be playable, I will change my review from a thumbs down!

Gacha bad.

So 65 hours played and i've reached annoyance stage. Can't progress in most game modes because they need mostly, if not fully upgraded characters to stand a chance of winning. So now i gotta wait around for months at a time, slowly farm dozens or hundreds of materials and millions of currency until the next roadblock hits or i can just pony up hundreds or thousands of $$ to do shit now, when i want to play.
So all that's left now is frustration waiting for me in the game because i know there's nothing i can do but wait. 

From my experience, you can get about 50 hours of pleasant gameplay time, which can be multiplied extensively by how much time you're willing to spend reading or listening to the many, many stories in the game.
The other 15 hours were spent allowing frustration taking over until it just isn't worth the pain anymore.

So yeah, gacha bad.

Maybe i'll get back to it from time to time and renew my frustration, but right now this is it for me.
the tutorials in this game are torture and the UI is a mess

The game doesn't work for me. It starts kind of interesting, but the writing and the voice acting murdered it in it's crib. I didn't even really get out of the tutorial because they keep talking and talking and talking about nothing with voices that don't match the situation.  I have played Arkknights. I have played Morimens (and that one is a machine translated mess, as far as grammar is concerned). I know this stuff can be done without me wanting to go do something else while the dialog plays.
The translation is actually pretty good, but the content just made me want to not play at all.

The game system itself seems to have potential - it's an interesting spin on slay the spire-esque card battling where you can combine your cards during the battle to get stronger effects.

From other comments I deduce that if you can stand the story you may have fun with this.

One of the most annoying community out there.
the game have so much to offer but the only thing that people talk to you is lesbian character.

When it is the weakest part of the game. 
I will let you know that most of the characters are just trauma personified and somehow trapped in some sort of Twilight-esque situationship with their female best friend or step sister.

And somehow that is the best part when they can read novel for young adult written by run of the mill authors such as John Green or Cassandra Claire.

What about the research that writers done to bring us tiny refrences to literary world. What about the gameplay and rotation pf each team. The fact that some unit designed to fill in a role specifically for certain line up.

I also think the "drama" between two characters is the weakest part. Since they read like something that comes put of YA novels. It made the dystopian background take backrow seat even when it is the more interesting part of the narrative.
Honestly just wasnt for me. The gacha is pitiful to like nothing in the beginning and I need to be able to jump into the game, do some pulls, and than go through all the content.
It‚Äôs a decent gacha. The mechanics remind me of Fate GGO but better as a system. The combat gets old though and it‚Äôs not even that good to look at.

Pretentious nonsense, on top of greedy monetization (the battle pass is offering crumbs) . Story is a salad of philosophy from around the world, by the time I reached the "good part", played a bit more and I decided to uninstall and forget I even played it to cleanse my mind of nonsense. I do not recommend.

I wish the characters would rerun more often but I really like the mood with the artstyle.
English voice is better on Sonetto because she stays monotone so I wanted to use that, but english is dog water on pretty much everyone else, kekw. I wish Sonetto's voice would be monotone in english too but they do not keep consitency in the personality of their way of talking as it seems.

Card system seems similar to Catfantasy, enjoyable but nothing crazy.
I wish you could have a select banner when you start out, like I really don't feel like waiting 10+ month to see a char i like.
Beautiful artwork. However, the story and battle are boring.
Too little pulls for f2p players
Somehow both boring and confusing

I do like this game and do recommend, but on mobile. PC gives me issues with the cinematics where I can hear the audio but just see a black screen; the summons are also a black screen; and so are the insight upgrades. It just makes for a tedious experience with missed content, especially in the later story chapters. The game is pretty good for a gacha and actually has a good story. The combat gets a little repetitive but its no big deal.

After wasting almost $4,500 in this game, I decided to quit and take a break for a while. Is this a bad game? Certainly not. But a mixed cash grab and gacha game with gl-bait.
I love reading visual novels, and the first four chapters of the story are quite decent. Then, suddenly, after being trapped by the amazing story of the first four chapters. Reverse 1999 showed its true form. A gacha game with decent arts, voice actings, and characters designs as its pros. But nothing more. The time-limited event is quite boring and left unfinished most of the time. You have to log in every day, grid(watch relay) countless time to earn your rewards. The packs in-store can only be purchased with real money or top-up currency. Otherwise, you have to log in and wait for its return, then buy it with real money lol.
Take this collab as an example, they introduce some new characters and new ways to play the game, also give you a chance to earn the character you like through 100 pulls, etc. Pity pulls imo, considering the devs already know how many players will suffer from the pull rate.
They also made some changes to old characters during this update as well, but after a few days, the new changes, in order to help old characters to catch up with the ridiculous damage requirements in the new events, are considered as bugs and fixed without any inform in advance(Vila). And after receiving a large number of complaints from the community, they decided to remain silent and do NOTHING about it. So players who got Vila in full and bought the new skin at the very first day have to surrfer from it. Wow, truly amazing.
So I personally recommend thinking twice before playing or spending real money on this game. Yes, it has its pros. But in the end, it's still a gacha game, developed by a CN company that treats its players as nothing but ATMs. And to think that their Twitter account is called 'reverse 1999_GL', lmao.

This video game is a photosensitive seizure waiting to happen to the untrained gamer at this magnitude of a 50 inch television. I am not saying that this videogame is horrible. I am addressing the safe gaming issue with epilepsy susceptible people I give this video game a 2.5 out of 5 broken controllers.

I didn't even really get out of the tutorial because they keep talking and talking and talking about nothing with voices that don't match the situation.  I have played Arkknights. I have played Morimens (and that one is a machine translated mess, as far as grammar is concerned). I know this stuff can be done without me wanting to go do something else while the dialog plays.
The translation is actually pretty good, but the content just made me want to not play at all.

The game system itself seems to have potential - it's an interesting spin on slay the spire-esque card battling where you can combine your cards during the battle to get stronger effects.

From other comments I deduce that if you can stand the story you may have fun with this.

One of the most annoying community out there.
the game have so much to offer but the only thing that people talk to you is lesbian character.

When it is the weakest part of the game. 
I will let you know that most of the characters are just trauma personified and somehow trapped in some sort of Twilight-esque situationship with their female best friend or step sister.

And somehow that is the best part when they can read novel for young adult written by run of the mill authors such as John Green or Cassandra Claire.

What about the research that writers done to bring us tiny refrences to literary world. What about the gameplay and rotation pf each team. The fact that some unit designed to fill in a role specifically for certain line up.

I also think the "drama" between two characters is the weakest part. Since they read like something that comes put of YA novels. It made the dystopian background take backrow seat even when it is the more interesting part of the narrative.
Honestly just wasnt for me. The gacha is pitiful to like nothing in the beginning and I need to be able to jump into the game, do some pulls, and than go through all the content.
It‚Äôs a decent gacha. The mechanics remind me of Fate GGO but better as a system. The combat gets old though and it‚Äôs not even that good to look at.

Pretentious nonsense, on top of greedy monetization (the battle pass is offering crumbs) . Story is a salad of philosophy from around the world, by the time I reached the "good part", played a bit more and I decided to uninstall and forget I even played it to cleanse my mind of nonsense. I do not recommend.

I wish the characters would rerun more often but I really like the mood with the artstyle.
English voice is better on Sonetto because she stays monotone so I wanted to use that, but english is dog water on pretty much everyone else, kekw. I wish Sonetto's voice would be monotone in english too but they do not keep consitency in the personality of their way of talking as it seems.

Card system seems similar to Catfantasy, enjoyable but nothing crazy.
I wish you could have a select banner when you start out, like I really don't feel like waiting 10+ month to see a char i like.
Beautiful artwork. However, the story and battle are boring.
Too little pulls for f2p players
Somehow both boring and confusing

I do like this game and do recommend, but on mobile. PC gives me issues with the cinematics where I can hear the audio but just see a black screen; the summons are also a black screen; and so are the insight upgrades. It just makes for a tedious experience with missed content, especially in the later story chapters. The game is pretty good for a gacha and actually has a good story. The combat gets a little repetitive but its no big deal.

Unplayable on Steamdeck

Before I downloaded the game, I looked into the game and its reviews. I heard good things about the game, so I decided to give it a try. My Wi-Fi isn‚Äôt the best, so it took a little over an hour to complete the download. Once downloaded, it did its in-game download, then went to the Home Screen after finishing. 

The cons:
The game has minimum customization optimizations in the settings, which is really no big deal for me. 
But the biggest issue I have is once I was ready to enter into the game from the home menu, I would encounter issues with screen blackout and the next 15 seconds of in-game audio.
I‚Äôm not sure if this happened to anyone else using the Steam Deck, but the screen would be black, and I could hear the audio for at least 15 seconds before it goes quiet!
I was able to move the cursor around, but the game doesn‚Äôt respond, even though it does acknowledge my cursor existence.
I tried resetting the game, uninstalling, and reinstalling the game. I even checked to see if everything was properly installed and not missing. Nothing works, and I‚Äôm very disappointed! 

The Pros: 
So far from my POV, the music is very harmonious, while the art style and scenes are very beautiful.
From the description, the game really has me intrigued, from the characters to the jaw-dropping scenes and story it has to tell! I really do want to play this game on the deck, but for some unknown reason, it just won‚Äôt play.

Until the game can be playable, I will change my review from a thumbs down!

After wasting almost $4,500 in this game, I decided to quit and take a break for a while. Is this a bad game? Certainly not. But a mixed cash grab and gacha game with gl-bait.
I love reading visual novels, and the first four chapters of the story are quite decent. Then, suddenly, after being trapped by the amazing story of the first four chapters. Reverse 1999 showed its true form. A gacha game with decent arts, voice actings, and characters designs as its pros. But nothing more. The time-limited event is quite boring and left unfinished most of the time. You have to log in every day, grid(watch relay) countless time to earn your rewards. The packs in-store can only be purchased with real money or top-up currency. Otherwise, you have to log in and wait for its return, then buy it with real money lol.
Take this collab as an example, they introduce some new characters and new ways to play the game, also give you a chance to earn the character you like through 100 pulls, etc. Pity pulls imo, considering the devs already know how many players will suffer from the pull rate.
They also made some changes to old characters during this update as well, but after a few days, the new changes, in order to help old characters to catch up with the ridiculous damage requirements in the new events, are considered as bugs and fixed without any inform in advance(Vila). And after receiving a large number of complaints from the community, they decided to remain silent and do NOTHING about it. So players who got Vila in full and bought the new skin at the very first day have to surrfer from it. Wow, truly amazing.
So I personally recommend thinking twice before playing or spending real money on this game. Yes, it has its pros. But in the end, it's still a gacha game, developed by a CN company that treats its players as nothing but ATMs. And to think that their Twitter account is called 'reverse 1999_GL', lmao.

This video game is a photosensitive seizure waiting to happen to the untrained gamer at this magnitude of a 50 inch television. I am not saying that this videogame is horrible. I am addressing the safe gaming issue with epilepsy susceptible people I give this video game a 2.5 out of 5 broken controllers.

Gacha bad.

So 65 hours played and i've reached annoyance stage. Can't progress in most game modes because they need mostly, if not fully upgraded characters to stand a chance of winning. So now i gotta wait around for months at a time, slowly farm dozens or hundreds of materials and millions of currency until the next roadblock hits or i can just pony up hundreds or thousands of $$ to do shit now, when i want to play.
So all that's left now is frustration waiting for me in the game because i know there's nothing i can do but wait. 

From my experience, you can get about 50 hours of pleasant gameplay time, which can be multiplied extensively by how much time you're willing to spend reading or listening to the many, many stories in the game.
The other 15 hours were spent allowing frustration taking over until it just isn't worth the pain anymore.

So yeah, gacha bad.

Maybe i'll get back to it from time to time and renew my frustration, but right now this is it for me.
